Journal.Title: Environmental science and pollution research international

Article.ArticleTitle: Artificial <sup>137</sup>Cs and natural <sup>40</sup>K in mushrooms from the subalpine region of the Minya Konka summit and Yunnan Province in China.

AbstractText: A study on <sup>137</sup>Cs pollution and activity concentrations of <sup>40</sup>K in mushrooms of the genera Cortinarius, Leccinum, Russula, Tricholoma, Tylopilus, and Xerocomus from two neighboring regions in southwest China in 2010-2013 revealed different patterns of pollution with <sup>137</sup>Cs, which seemed to be highly dependent on climate conditions. Tricholoma matsutake was collected in Yunnan before and after the Fukushima Dai-ichi nuclear accident and showed similar contamination with <sup>137</sup>Cs. Mushrooms from the elevation of 2800-3480 m above sea level on the east slope of Minya Konka and forest topsoil showed higher contamination with <sup>137</sup>Cs than mushrooms from the highlands of Yunnan. In detail, the activity concentration of <sup>137</sup>Cs in caps of mushrooms from Minya Konka were in the range 62 ± 6-280 ± 150 Bq kg<sup>-1</sup> dry biomass and from Yunnan at < 4.4-83 ± 3 Bq kg<sup>-1</sup> dry biomass. The climate in the region of the Minya Konka is much colder than in Yunnan, which seems to favor deposition of <sup>137</sup>Cs at higher altitudes from global atmospheric circulation. The activity concentration of <sup>40</sup>K in mushrooms and soils highly exceeded that of <sup>137</sup>Cs. The assessed annual effective doses for <sup>137</sup>Cs in 1 kg of consumed mushrooms of the genera Leccinum and Xerocomus in Yunnan were low, i.e., in the range < 0.0043-0.049 ± 0.004 μSv, while those for <sup>40</sup>K were 0.26 ± 0.02-0.81 ± 0.09 μSv.
